_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stadelman Fruit, LLC, a Washington Corporation, located in Yakima County, City of Zillah, is a cherry processing warehouse.  The facility was built in 2016 in accordance with specifications approved by ANSI/IIAR.  All pressure vessels were built according to American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code.  Construction meets published standards, tests or recommended method of trade, industry and governmental agencies.  



The refrigeration system uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is considered a hazardous substance by EPA, with the threshold quantity being 10,000 lbs.  Currently the system contains approximately 15,200 lbs, which requires reporting to EPA.  It is the policy of Stadelman Fruit to be in compliance with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  



The safety of our employees, neighbors and the environment are very important to Stadelman Fruit.  While the design of the facility incorporates a multitude of safety devices, Standard Operating Procedures combined with appropriate training of our personnel are important to maintaining safety at our facility.  Some safety devices utilized are:



   Suction trap hi level floats

   High discharge pressure shut down

   Low suction pressure shut down

   High discharge temperature shut down

   Oil pressure failure shut down

   250 psi relief valves on high pressure side (to prevent overpressure situations)

   High amperes shut down

   Automatic timer to prevent short cycling

   Oil filters plugged shut down



Stadelman Fruit has a written Process Safety Management (PSM) plan that complies with the regulations stipulated by WAC 296-67-017, including an Emergency Action Plan, developed in compliance with the Emergency Response provisions of WAC 296-62-3112.  The Emergency Action Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordination with our local emergency responder.  It is the policy of Stadelman Fruit not to respond to la

rge releases of ammonia.  Therefore, employees are trained on evacuation procedures at least once every year.  The responding fire or hazmat team will take control of the scene upon arrival.  Other preventative measures are found in our process hazard assessment, hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, management of change, hot work permits and compliance audit programs. `
